And what this Court has said about statute of limitations, including in the Day case, is that the trial court doesn't have an obligation to serve as the ­­ the co­counsel or the paralegal for ­­ for the defendant. It doesn't have an obligation to go searching through the record and finding potential defenses for the defendant. Rather, that's something that the defendant himself has an obligation to do.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ALITO
completeLines.speech: Suppose the court of appeals in ­­ in a direct appeal sees that the statute of limitations for a particular offense is six years and the indictment was filed 25 years after the event. completeLines.speaker: MARTINEZ
completeLines.speech: I ­­ I think that the ­­ the ­­ the better way is to wait until habeas to ­­ to correct that. And the reason for that is that Rule 52(b) is limited to the existing record. completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KAGAN
completeLines.speech: Well, that might be true sometimes, but it doesn't seem as though that's the ordinary case. completeLines.speaker: MARTINEZ
completeLines.speech: I think I appreciate the ­­ I ­­ the sort of practical concern embedded in that question. I think as a formal matter you would still need to be looking outside the record.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: Why formal? I mean, we've been through this many times. It comes up in all kinds of instances. completeLines.speaker: MARTINEZ
completeLines.speech: Right.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: And therefore I think every circuit ­­ I don't know what this Court has said ­­ has said that you raise IAC claims in collateral proceedings. Now, if we start making exceptions from that, you're going to get a jurisprudence of when the exception comes up ­­

completeLines.speaker: MARTINEZ
completeLines.speech: I think ­­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: ­­ and when it doesn't and how clear does it have to be, and then we'll just add further delay because I guess if I were a court of appeals judge and I saw some obvious mistake, I would say, go file it tomorrow.

completeLines.speaker: MARTINEZ
completeLines.speech: Right. And I ­­ and I think that's the better way to handle this because the alternative is to ­­ to ­­ because we see some cases that look like they'd be pretty easy to decide, is to say, well, let's ­­ let's erode what would otherwise be pretty hard­and­fast rules about how Rule 52(b) is supposed to operate. completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE GINSBURG
completeLines.speech: Of course ­­ of course, if there was a ­­ a strong statute­of­limitations bar, isn't it likely that the trial judge would suggest to defense counsel, don't you want to raise a ­­ a limitations defense?

completeLines.speaker: MARTINEZ
completeLines.speech: I think that's very, very likely that the trial court might do that. completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: What type of strategic reason are you talking about?

completeLines.speaker: MARTINEZ
completeLines.speech: Well, I think there ­­ there could be a couple of them. In this case, for example, the ­­ the original indictment was undoubtedly filed within the limitations period. completeLines.speech: Could you summarize for me your position on three arguments he made.

completeLines.speech: So ­­ so on ­­ on his claim for de novo review on appeal, we think that's inconsistent with Rule 52(b), and we think that that misreads Wood and Day, the habeas cases, because those are really about the habeas context. For there to be an error, we think the statute of limitations would need to be something that the ­­ the trial court is supposed to have an obligation to sort out. completeLines.speech: So what would you argue if this was brought up on habeas?

completeLines.speaker: MARTINEZ
completeLines.speech: On habeas?

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
completeLines.speech: Let's assume counsel comes in and says, I just didn't notice it.

completeLines.speaker: MARTINEZ
completeLines.speech: In this particular case, Your Honor?

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
completeLines.speech: Yes. And ­­ and it's very clear ­­ and the evidence was super clear that this was past the statute of limitations. I don't want to get into the facts of this case.

completeLines.speaker: MARTINEZ
completeLines.speech: Well, I ­­ I ­­ I think ­­ I think ­­ in some cases, I think it would be fair for ­­ for the parties to litigate why the defense wasn't raised. completeLines.speaker: JAFFE
completeLines.speech: On the issue of whether or not the jury instructions are binding, several points: First of all, the confusion persists to this day. Second of all, I believe that Jackson v. Virginia talks from a jury­centric perspective. The issue is not the statute. The issue is whether a rational jury could have done what they did. And that only works if you look at the instructions. It does not work if you look at some hypothetical statute that they didn't think they were applying. They thought they were doing something different. Third, their objection that we ­­ we acknowledged that this was only about unauthorized access is curious because he cites the appellate stuff where there was new counsel, yet his own side's briefs at the trial level recognized that trial counsel was confused. Yes, after that confusion was resolved post­verdict, we argued. Okay. The government abandoned it. That's fine. We absolutely argued that. But at trial the harm was already done. They confused themselves, they confused the jury, and apparently confused the judge. Third, it seems to me that the phrase "unauthorized access" is not actually even in the statute, which just goes to my point that there would be confusion as to access without authorization and access exceeding authorization. Both could have theoretically been part of the rubric of unauthorized access. Neither would be authorized there. The ­­ moving onto the ­­ well, I guess the last thing I'd say is every court to consider the question, if this had been in the original indictment where it also said "and" and in the jury instructions, every court to consider this issue, including the Fifth Circuit below, including the First Circuit, would have held the government to it. But if it's in the indictment and in the instructions, they concede that the so­called law of the case is binding. The easy way for this Court to ­­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE GINSBURG
completeLines.speech: The law of the case you ­­ you are ­­ you are asserting that, if there is a mistake but it's the law of the case, that applies on appeal. As ­­ and I thought that law of the case applied to the same court, different stages of litigation, not that a ­­ a court of appeals has to perpetuate a trial court error.

completeLines.speaker: JAFFE
completeLines.speech: Law of the case is a terrible name. We unfortunately didn't come up with it. The government ­­ we both agree that it's not an accurate descriptor. Turning to the statute of limitations, what I'd say is this: There is error when something is contrary to law whether or not it was the judge's obligation to raise that.
